Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Understanding water availability through the modeling of groundwater flow and temperature of the Heihe River in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
A warming climate in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau in China has led to decreases in permafrost extent and water insecurity. While it is speculated that there will be large-scale changes in water resource availability, it is unknown at what magnitude and rate these changes will occur. To test this, a three-dimensional, groundwater flow and temperature model will be developed for the Hulugou watershed, the headwaters of the Heihe River located on the northern edge of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Sihai Liang, a noted expert on quantitative hydrology and the Hulugou watershed, at the China University of Geosciences in Beijing. Conducting this research in China affords a unique opportunity to gather necessary field measurements. This research will help the hydrologic community by providing new knowledge on the effect of climatic changes on regional water resources.

This project will investigate how thawing and freezing permafrost affects groundwater storage and movement. A coupled hydrogeologic model will incorporate the physics of water phase change, allowing for modeling of pore water freeze and thaw and permeability dependence on ice saturation. Model inputs will be constrained and calibrated by collecting and analyzing new field data from the Hulugou watershed. Major outcomes of the model will include: spatial and temporal distributions of subsurface temperature, fluid pressure, groundwater recharge, and discharge to the land surface. Model results will corroborate relationships between climatic effects on this watershed and a similar watershed in the Rocky Mountains in Colorado. While these two watersheds are under similar climatic stresses and both potentially experiencing declines in water resources, underlying causes may differ. This NSF EAPSI is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Climatic warming is hypothesized to result in permafrost degradation. This result will have adverse consequences on groundwater magnitude and movement in high-latitude, headwater watersheds. It is critical to understand the effect of warming on groundwater flow in these watersheds, as headwater watersheds have a direct impact on the water resources of downstream regions. This project characterized groundwater flow for a headwater watershed and evaluated the effect of permafrost on groundwater movement. A three-dimensional, finite element, hydrogeologic model of the Hulugou Watershed, located on the northern edge of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, provided the basis for this investigation. This research was conducted in collaboration with Dr. Sihai Liang, a noted expert on quantitative hydrology and the Hulugou watershed, at the China University of Geosciences in Beijing.

 Results from this project indicate the following: (1) baseflow constitutes the majority (53%) of streamflow, (2) in areas of permafrost, the majority of flow is in the active layer, with a few deep, regional groundwater flowpaths, in permafrost free areas, flow is concentrated in nested, shallow flow paths, and (3) permafrost acts as an effective confining layer that may lead to changes in baseflow magnitude and sources. These results imply that groundwater, in the form of baseflow, plays an important role in streamflow generation for headwater catchments. They also highlight the impact of permafrost as a confining layer on groundwater flow.

Conducting this research in China afforded a unique opportunity to gather necessary data and collaborate international with other scientists in hydrogeology. Through this work, long-lasting scientific partnerships have been formed with fellow female graduate students from the China University of Geosciences and Peking University in Beijing. These collaborations are very beneficial as females are still vastly underrepresented in the discipline of hydrogeology. This research has helped the hydrologic community by providing new knowledge on the effect of climatic changes on regional water resources.
